Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Hughes Closure vs. Standard Mass Closure in Colorectal Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size calculation aimed for 800 patients, anticipating 20% loss to follow-up.

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing midline incision for colorectal cancer were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to Hughes closure (double far–near–near–far sutures with conventional mass closure) or standard closure

Objective.evidence: This trial assessed the effect of Hughes closure on incisional hernia incidence following colorectal cancer surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of incisional hernia at 1 year, assessed by clinical examination.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed in the operating theatre using a 1:1 computerized adaptive system, with allocation concealment by Sealed Envelope.

Blinding.evidence: Patients and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From August 2014 to February 2018, 802 patients were randomised (401 per group).

Number_Analysed.evidence: At 1 year, 672 patients were analysed (339 Hughes, 333 standard) using intention-to-treat.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Incisional hernia occurred in 14.8% of Hughes and 17.1% of standard groups (OR 0.84, 95% CI 0.55 to 1.27; P = 0.402).

Harms.evidence: Surgical-site infections were higher in the Hughes group (13.2% vs. 7.7%; OR 1.82, 1.14 to 2.91; P = 0.011).

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial is registered under ISRCTN25616490.

Funding.evidence: Funding was provided by the National Institute for Health Research.
